user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_try_alloc:
```c
void *
MHD_pool_try_alloc (struct MemoryPool *pool,
                    size_t size,
                    size_t *required_bytes)
{
  void *ret;
  size_t asize;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  asize = ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE (size);
  if ( (0 == asize) && (0 != size) )
  { /* size is too close to SIZE_MAX, very unlikely */
    *required_bytes = SIZE_MAX;
    return NULL;
  }
  if (asize > pool->end - pool->pos)
  {
    mhd_assert ((pool->end - pool->pos) == \
                ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->end - pool->pos));
    if (asize <= pool->end)
      *required_bytes = asize - (pool->end - pool->pos);
    else
      *required_bytes = SIZE_MAX;
    return NULL;
  }
  *required_bytes = 0;
  ret = &pool->memory[pool->end - asize];
  pool->end -= asize;
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (ret, size);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected the two conditional branches that handle (a) the case where the computed aligned size became zero while the requested size was nonzero (overflow/wraparound), and (b) the branch for insufficient pool space (including its two subcases assigning required_bytes). These are the code paths most likely to be provably unreachable depending on the definitions/constraints of ROUND_TO_ALIGN_PLUS_RED_ZONE, the pool fields, and SIZE_MAX handling, so they warrant investigation.

Other parts of the function do not need further investigation for unreachable-code concerns: the final allocation path (setting required_bytes = 0, computing ret = &pool->memory[pool->end - asize], adjusting pool->end, unpoisoning memory, and returning ret) is the normal reachable path when asize <= pool->end - pool->pos. The mhd_assert(...) statements are diagnostic checks (typically compiled out in non-debug builds) and do not introduce runtime unreachable code by themselves. No other branches or statements in the function appear to be unconditionally unreachable given the surrounding logic, so they were not included.
